content.question: A. Using the information in the table of reduction potentials, calculate the value of the standard reduction potential, <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>E</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, for <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: A. Using the information in the table of reduction potentials, calculate the value of the standard reduction potential, <math alttext="E naught" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>E</mi> <mi>°</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, for <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

B. A commercially available <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mtext>D</mtext> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> cell is typically able to provide a current of <math alttext="0.200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ampere for <math alttext="20.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours. Assuming that <math alttext="Zn" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <semantics> <mrow> <mtext>Zn</mtext> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahGart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGAbGaaeOBaa aa@3ACC@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> is the reactant in excess, calculate the minimum number of moles of <math alttext="M n O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>MnO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that are used in the <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cell as it provides the current.

C. The chemical reaction that occurs in small <math alttext="double A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells is the same as that on which <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells operate. A student claims that the cell potential of the larger <math alttext="D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>D</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells would have to be greater than the cell potential of the smaller <math alttext="double A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> cells. Do you agree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
